title: A judgment was entered against me back in 2006 by National Credit Acceptance (NCA) for a debt that is about 10 years old($1800).
question: I paid the amount down to $1000 but after 3 years, NCA was sued for bad practice and went out of business. New owner of debt is SACOR which is probably the same people but a different name. Between 2009 and early 2011 NCA was going out of business and I couldn’t get a hold of them to pay the account. Here’s the situation:
answers:
You have the right to tender the $757 to the Clerk of Court and have the Clerk enter a satisfaction of judgment.

You should do so filing the form (link below) called SC-145 "Request to Pay Judgment to Court". Since your judgment is under the small claims amount this form would be sufficient.

I would also contemplate filing a lawsuit against the creditor for adding costs and interest to the judgment which were not authorized or awarded by the Court. That would violate Cal. B&PC 17200 and the Civil Legal Remedies Act. That would be actionable, possibly, as a class action if it turns out they've turned the screw on a lot of other debtors such as yourself.

Their having a bad reputation no the internet is not admissible in any court proceeding. There are a few things that should be checked, and you may want to consult an attorney to review everything. Was there an assignment of the judgment filed with the court? Is the new creditor properly qualified to do business in California? Do the new creditor have an attorney of record who is licensed to practice law in California? Is your current address corrected shown on the court records? In order to claim interest or post judgment court costs, the judgment creditor must file and serve a Memorandum of Costs After Judgment. If this document is served and filed (which is done by an attorney who is properly licensed to practice law in California and who has properly appeared as attorney of record in the action), you can file a "Motion to Tax Costs", and get a court hearing to determine the proper amount of interest and court costs. If you pay (or tender payment), and they do not execute a Satisfaction of Judgment, you can bring a motion in court and get the court to enter an order and, also, get attorney's fees and costs.

Also, you might have a separate lawsuit against these people for violating the FDCPA by demanding payment of an amount which is more than what you actually owe. You will need to be able to prove your case. If so, you can recover up to $1,000 as a penalty for each violation, any actual damages and your attorney's fees.

Your best option may be to make a summary of everything that's happened in relation to this debt, and speak to a consumer attorney, to see if you have a cause of action against this debt collector and any law firm that represents the collector. If you dispute the debt, the creditor must show that the amount demanded is the correct amount. If they cannot do that, do not pay them.

Sounds like they might be violating Fair Debt Collection Practices act. You can either complain to an Attorney General, or contact a debt collection attorney. You may have a potential claim but an attorney will have to see the actual paperwork to better advise you. Most of us provide free consultations.
